ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to do policy-oriented research and present it concisely. What incentives should you keep in mind as you decide what material to highlight?
I learned the most from the speakers which we had during the class, which I think was really the strength of the class.
I learned about the interdisciplinary nature of global health studies and about how to prepare a policy brief.

I learned a lot about decolonizing global health, current global health governance structures, and got to engage more passionately and deeply with potential global health careers, finalizing the path I hope to take in the future. I really appreciated being able to undertake the policy brief and produce something I was super proud of, engaging with Scholars I didn't know as well before the course and really ended up enjoying working with.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course's ability to attract real-life practitioners was great. It felt like what we learning in school actually made a difference. To be improved: class hours!

The strenghts of the class were the speaker events that we had, I learned a lot from those. But the set up of the class was a real weakness. The class sections were sometimes combined, and sometimes separate, which meant that the time was different a lot of weeks, and also some students hardly came to the class cause it overlapped with another class they were taking.

The policy brief portion of the course felt incredibly rushed. We were only given roughly a month to understand our assignment, speak with mentors, and create the policy brief. Being that this was the first policy brief many of us created, it felt incredibly difficult to complete this task, especially considering that we didn't have structured class periods during this time.

I think it was difficult for some people to see the speakers but overall I really loved our readings and discussion. I thought the in-class critical analysis was a little stressful and was held to a higher standard than I expected for an in class essay, but the class overall was so amazing and I really engaged with the texts.

Timing of the course was difficult; the seminar is split into two sections, but near the end of the semester we are assigned into teams from across different sections. I was the only member from one section, so the rest of the team could easily meet while I had an overlapping class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes it was definitely a very engaging and interesting class, with hands on learning. Not the most taxing class workload wise
I would absolutely recommend this course. It provides exposure to such cool topics and an opportunity to connect with real-life experts.
It is required, so if you are a GHS, then yes. But really it changes every year, so the evalutations will not be that helpful to future students.

Yes, it was a great opportunity to learn about real world examples of global health issues, meet inspiring people in the field, and develop interdisciplinary thinking skills necessary for global health work.
I definitely think that this is a great part of the Global Health Scholars curriculum and I enjoyed our trips and being able to meet and talk with people working in the global health space as well.
